content.raw: Hi, right now Gazebo doesn't explicitly support self-describing messages and this capability is not on our roadmap. However, don't let this stop you from creating (and ideally submtting) a solution.
content.html: Hi, right now Gazebo doesn't explicitly support self-describing messages and this capability is not on our roadmap. However, don't let this stop you from creating (and ideally submtting) a solution.

content.raw:
Hi @nkoenig! Thanks for your feedback! Yes I will definitely work towards bringing this to reality. Though, do you mind to actually give some initial guidance and references on the API of where I should look into to actually make this possible? That would boost my development and would put me on the right track without having to dig into parts of the API which are not actually required.

Thank you very much for that!

content.raw:
Can you describe you use-case in a bit more detail first? What version of gazebo are you using? What is generating custom messages, for example a plugin? And, what is consuming the messages?

Or, do you want `gz topic -e <topic>` to work on custom messages?
content.html:
Can you describe you use-case in a bit more detail first? What version of gazebo are you using? What is generating custom messages, for example a plugin? And, what is consuming the messages?

Or, do you want gz topic -e <topic> to work on custom messages?

content.raw:
Hello @nkoenig! Again, thanks for your feedback.

The specific use case is [sitl_gazebo](https://github.com/PX4/sitl_gazebo), which is a collection of plugins, models and messages for simulation of sensors, components, control and estimation of flying vehicles. What we are looking in specific is of a way of yes, having `gztopic -e <topic>` to echo the messages that are generated and consumed by the plugins in `sitl_gazebo`. The collection of custom messages is present [here](https://github.com/PX4/sitl_gazebo/tree/master/msgs).
I have started by taking a look on what does the `Echo` command do in the [`gz_topic.cc`](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/820440c98cd2fa17480ff66e5306bf4183db68da/tools/gz_topic.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#lines-208) and I found it depends on the type of the message that you set on the [`Publisher` class](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/820440c98cd2fa17480ff66e5306bf4183db68da/gazebo/transport/Publisher.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#lines-42). My understanding is that when we create a publisher we also have to pass the type, so is it right to consider that for self-describing messages, the type should be set automatically if there's a positive check for self-describable message? Or am I completely out of what is supposed to be addressed and this is actually something substantially more simple? Any tips you can give?

Thanks in advance!
content.html:
Hello @nkoenig! Again, thanks for your feedback.

The specific use case is sitl_gazebo, which is a collection of plugins, models and messages for simulation of sensors, components, control and estimation of flying vehicles. What we are looking in specific is of a way of yes, having gztopic -e <topic> to echo the messages that are generated and consumed by the plugins in sitl_gazebo. The collection of custom messages is present here. I have started by taking a look on what does the Echo command do in the gz_topic.cc and I found it depends on the type of the message that you set on the Publisher class. My understanding is that when we create a publisher we also have to pass the type, so is it right to consider that for self-describing messages, the type should be set automatically if there's a positive check for self-describable message? Or am I completely out of what is supposed to be addressed and this is actually something substantially more simple? Any tips you can give?

Thanks in advance!

content.raw: @nkoenig any input you can give here? This would help me speed up this. Thanks!
content.html: @nkoenig any input you can give here? This would help me speed up this. Thanks!

content.raw:
You are correct that when creating a publisher you have to specify the type. We have never used self-describing messages before, so there is no mechanism to determine if a message is self-describing or not. You could add logic to gazebo transport system to check for self-describing messages. I haven't looked into the feasibility of this. I think it would require some experimentation.

Alternatively, you could use [Ignition Transport](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport). This is transport is used by parts of gazebo9, and is the transport system for our current development efforts. You can use ignition transport in conjunction with gazebo's legacy transport system, and the API looks very similar. I bring up this option because you can echo topics without using self-describing messages.
content.html:
You are correct that when creating a publisher you have to specify the type. We have never used self-describing messages before, so there is no mechanism to determine if a message is self-describing or not. You could add logic to gazebo transport system to check for self-describing messages. I haven't looked into the feasibility of this. I think it would require some experimentation.

Alternatively, you could use Ignition Transport. This is transport is used by parts of gazebo9, and is the transport system for our current development efforts. You can use ignition transport in conjunction with gazebo's legacy transport system, and the API looks very similar. I bring up this option because you can echo topics without using self-describing messages.

content.raw:
Dear @nkoenig I tried to follow your suggestion on using ignition Transport. I set up a publisher using ignition Transport Publisher in a plugin and, in another plugin, I setup the Subscriber, also from ignition Transport. I can see that the data is exchanged between the plugins, though, using `ign-tools`, more in specific, the echo tool, again, I am not able to echo any data coming from the publisher.

The publisher is setup like the following:
```c++
ignition::transport::Node::Publisher m_baro_pub_ign_;
...
m_baro_pub_ign_ = node_ign_.Advertise<sensor_msgs::msgs::Baro>("/gazebo/default/" + m_model->GetName() + m_baro_topic);
...
m_baro_pub_ign_.Publish(msg);
```

the subscriber is setup as follows:
```
node_ign_.Subscribe("/gazebo/default/" + model_->GetName() + baro_sub_topic_, &GazeboMotorModel::BaroCallback_, this)

void GazeboMotorModel::BaroCallback_(const sensor_msgs::msgs::Baro &baro_msg)
{
  ...
}
```

If I try to echo the topic using `ign topic --echo -t /gazebo/default/<model_name>/baro`, nothing is echoed, which leads me to think that the `ign-tools` is not able to process custom protobuf messages as gz-tools (only ignition messages or generic protobuf messages).

Also another note: I am not able to plug a Gazebo Transport publisher with a ignition Transport subscriber and vice-versa, using a custom protobuf messages, so that's why I decided to apply a publisher and a subscriber of the same type (ignition Transport). So I question the compatibility between the legacy Gazebo transport and the ignition Tranport for custom messages.

Any tip you can give here?

the subscriber is setup as follows:

Also another note: I am not able to plug a Gazebo Transport publisher with a ignition Transport subscriber and vice-versa, using a custom protobuf messages, so that's why I decided to apply a publisher and a subscriber of the same type (ignition Transport). Any tip you can give here?
